item.content:encoded:
Willem J. de Wit writes a helpful introduction to Wageeh Y. F. Mikhail’s recent dissertation at the University of Birmingham on a forgotten ninth-century Christian theologian who lived in an Islamic context: ‘Ammār al-Baṣrī’s Kitāb al-Burhān: a topical and theological analysis of Arabic Christian theology in the ninth century (PDF; 445 pp.; 2 MB). This welcome study includes the first English translation of ‘Ammār’s Kitāb al-Burhān.

In class last fall I tried to emphasize the need for us Western Christians to listen to and learn from our Eastern adelphoi with respect to Christian-Muslim relations. Mikhail’s study looks to be an important and much useful tool for this purpose. Along this line de Wit asks, in reference to ‘Ammār’s Christian musing on Islam: “could it be that, at least in some respects, the Arabs are centuries ahead of Europeans and Americans?” I hope we Western Evangelicals are ready with a quick “yes!”
